text: all normally among the most polite of
teaching unions the National Association
of head teachers gave Nikki Morgan's
academies programme an angry reaction
last week mrs Morgan faced shouted
interruptions and hostile questions this
is not about pass or fail or targeting
people the union's president told her to
make a better job of justifying the
policy he welcomed her decision to back
down it's a very good to hear that Nicky
Morgan has welcomed the comments that we
made too and she started to think about
the way in which schools can be
structured and she recognizes that
forcing schools become academies is not
the answer there's still a lot of work
that needs to be done around funding
when welcome the opportunity to debate
that further the government still
intends to for schools to convert we're
a council has very few remaining under
its control or is performing badly but
no small rural schools can be closed
unless councils agree Nicky Morgan
insisted that making schools academies
did improve them we absolutely support
those strong local authorities where
schools are good and outstanding they
can make the choice to convert I hope
that they will because we are convinced
that the coming academies does lift
standards but they can do the right
thing for them and reflects the concerns
and the conversations that we have had
it's unlikely that mrs. Morgan's
embarrassing climbdown will silence her
critics for long Union say she now needs
to tackle a shortage of funding and
problems recruiting teachers Robert
pickets BBC News
